awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Thermal Investigation of Strain-Tuned Thermal Conductivities of Thin Films
awd_abstract_narration:
Strained nanofilms are widely used in electronic and optoelectronic devices, microelectromechanical systems, photovoltaics, light-emitting diodes, and for solid-state energy conversion. However, the thermal properties of a strained film have not yet been systematically investigated. This collaborative project aims to study the impact of a high tensile strain (up to 1-10% depending on the film thickness) on the thermal properties of representative thin films that are of technologically important materials in current electronic industry. Outcomes of this work can particularly benefit their broad industrial applications with the preference of thin-film geometry for device fabrication. More broadly, the obtained knowledge can be potentially generalized to other nanostructured materials for strain-engineered properties. This project can benefit a general public through materials discoveries at museum exhibitions, development of interdisciplinary education and research programs at two universities, and creation of new outreach activities to K-12 and high-school students. 

This proposed work will establish a comprehensive understanding on the thermal properties of ?elastic strain engineered? nanofilms, with an emphasis on the thermal anisotropy along both the tensile-strain and the transverse directions. A series of systematic temperature-dependent thermal transport studies will be carried out on representative thin films under uniaxial and equi-biaxial tensile strains, via the integration of the state-of-the-art ultrafast pump-probe experimental technique and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. New physical insights will be gained, particularly, into the usually overlooked transverse-direction phonon transport. In addition, by tuning the spot sizes and frequencies of laser heating in the pump-probe experiments, the in-plane phonon mean-free-path (MFP) spectrum will also be reconstructed. Such a phonon MFP spectrum will be further used for the phonon transport analysis of strained films, in comparison with numerous studies on unstrained bulk materials. The knowledge gained from thin-film studies can be potentially extended to other nanostructures (e.g., nanowires and 2D materials) and nanostructured bulk materials (e.g., nanocomposites hot pressed under an ultrahigh pressure).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For this proposed project, our collaborative team (Wang's group at UMN and Hao's group at UA) explored the impact of strain-induced structural modification on thermal transport in representative thin films. At the fundamental level, a better scientific understanding of the strain-property relationship provides important guidance for "strain engineering" that is widely used to tune the thermal, ionic, electrical, catalytic, and optical properties of materials for various applications, including high-power and high-voltage electronics, thermoelectrics, photovoltaics, and spintronics.

 

The scientific outcomes generated over the project period mainly include one Book Chapter, eight journal papers (two papers highlighted as Editor's Pick and one paper selected as Cover Art), one conference presentation, and four invited talks. 

Invited IOP book chapter:

- Lattery, D., Zhu, J., Huang, Dingbin, Wang, X.J., 2019-2020, "Ultrafast Thermal and Magnetic Measurements Enabled by Time-Resolved Magneto-Optical Kerr Effect", invited IOP Book Chapter on Nanoscale Energy Transport, Emerging Phenomena, Methods, and Applications, pp. 9-1 to 9-30. 

Journal papers:

- Zhang, Y.Y., Huang, D.B., Zhang, C., Wang, X.J., 2022, "The Spin-Heat Coupling and Enabling Applications", Journal of Applied Physics, 131, p. 040902 [Editor's pick]. AIP Scilight highlight: https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/10.0009484

- Song, Y.W., Shoemaker, D., Leach, J., McGray, C., Huang, H.L., Bhattacharyya, A., Zhang, Y.Y.,..., Wang, X.J., Krishnamoorthy, S., Hwang, J., Foley, B., Choi, S., 2021, "Ga2O3-on-SiC Composite Wafer for Thermal Management of Ultra-Wide Bandgap Electronics", ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, 13 (34), pp. 40817-40829.

- Song, Y.W., Ranga, P., Zhang, Y.Y.,..., Wang, X.J., Krishnamoorthy, S., Foley, B., Choi, S., 2021, "Thermal Conductivity of β-phase Ga2O3 and (AlxGa1-x)2O3 Heteroepitaxial Thin Films", ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, 13 (32), pp. 38477-38490.

- Thompson, M.F., Wu, X.W., Huang, D.B., Zhang, Y.Y., Seaton, N.C.A., Zhang, C., Johnson, M.T., Podkaminer, J.P., Ho, V., Wang, X.J., 2021, "Direct Measurements of Thermal Transport in Glass and Ceramic Microspheres Embedded in an Epoxy Matrix", Applied Physics Letters, 119, p. 023904 [Editor's pick]. AIP Scilight highlight: https://aip.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/10.0005674

- Huang, D.B., Lattery, D., Wang, X.J., 2020, "Materials Engineering Enabled by Time-Resolved Magneto-Optical Kerr Effect for Spintronic Applications", ACS Applied Electronic Materials, 3(1), pp. 119-127.

- Wu, X.W., Greenberg, B.L., Zhang, Y.Y., Held, J. H., Huang, D.B., Barriocanal, J.G., Mkhoyan, K.A., Aydil, E.S., Kortshagen, U.R., Wang, X.J., 2020, "Thermal Transport in ZnO Nanocrystal Networks Synthesized by Nonthermal Plasma", Physical Review Materials, 4, p. 086001. 

- Feng, T.L., Wu, X.W., Yang, X.L., Wang, P.P., Zhang, L.Y., Du, X., Wang, X.J., and Pantelides, S.T., 2019, "Thermal Conductivity of HfTe5: A Critical Revisit", Advanced Functional Materials, 30(5), p. 1907286 [cover image]. 

- Zhu, J., Feng, T.L., Mills, S., Wang, P.P., Wu, X.W., Zhang, L.Y., Pantelides, S.T., Du, X., Wang, X.J., 2018, "Record-Low and Anisotropic Thermal Conductivity of Quasi-1D Bulk ZrTe5 Single Crystal", ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, 10(47), pp. 40740-40747. 

Conference presentations:

- "Experimental Study of Thermal Transport in Strained Silicon Thin Films", Xuewang Wu, Fabian Javier Medina, Dongchao Xu, Lis Stolik, Xiaojia Wang and Qing Hao, abstract #: MNHMT2019-4274, the 6th ASME International Conference of Micro/Nanoscale Heat and Mass Transfer, Dalian, China, July 9-10, 2019.

Invited talks:

- "Ultrafast Optical Measurements of Transport Properties of Functional Materials", MRS Fall Meeting 2020, Nov. 29 - Dec 04. 2020, virtual.

- "Study of Thermal and Magnetic Transport in Functional Materials Enabled by Ultrafast Optical Metrology". V-Materials2021, the 2nd Edition of Materials Science and Nanoscience Webinar, Apr. 16-17, 2021, virtual.

- "Thermal and Magnetic Transport in Materials", Jun. 2019, Telluride Conference on "Thermal Transport at the Nanoscale", Telluride, CO.

- "Engineering Thermal Transport in Polymeric Materials and Nanocomposite for Thermal Management", Jun. 2019, 3M Corporate Headquarters, St. Paul, MN. 

 

On a broader level, the project outcomes have been disseminated to the public and the scientific community through publications and professional presentations. PI Wang hosted lab tours for 8-12th grade girls in STEM discipline and also gave tutorial lectures to the 2020 REU undergraduate students in the ME department at the University of Minnesota (due to the COVID impact, these events were in the virtual format). The topic of "strain engineering of functional materials for thermal management" was successfully integrated into the lecture modules of two graduate-level courses (Radiation and Heat Transfer Physics). In addition, Wang disseminated results from this project at several invited talks, including both professional conferences/workshops and industrial seminars. On the mentoring and training aspects, this project benefitted four Ph.D. students (two females) and four undergraduate researchers (one female). Among the four Ph.D. students, one student graduated in 2019 and is now a senior engineer at Seagate. Another female student will graduate by the end of this year and then start a new job at Intel.
